verses.text: Simon Peter, a servant and apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who have obtained a faith as precious as ours by the righteousness of our God and Savior Jesus Christ:
verses.comment: Peter opens by affirming both his role as servant and apostle. The use of 'our God and Savior Jesus Christ' is a high Christology statement, affirming Christ's divinity (see also Titus 2:13). The recipients have obtained the same 'precious faith', echoing unity in belief, and the means of faith is God's righteousness, not human effort.

verses.text: May grace and peace be multiplied to you in the knowledge of God and of Jesus our Lord.
verses.comment: This standard apostolic greeting links grace and peace with coming to know God and Jesus, underscoring the inseparability of unity with Christ and blessing. The knowledge mentioned here is more relational than simply intellectual.

verses.text: His divine power has granted us all things that pertain to life and godliness, through the knowledge of Him who called us by His own glory and excellence.
verses.comment: God’s power provides everything necessary for life and godliness, not through self-reliance, but through knowing Him. The calling is rooted in His glory and excellence, reminding the reader of the call to holiness (see Eph. 1:4).

verses.text: Through these He has given us His very great and precious promises, so that through them you may become partners in the divine nature, having escaped from the corruption that is in the world because of evil desire.
verses.comment: Participating in the 'divine nature' points to the transformation believers undergo, sometimes referred to as theosis. Escaping corruption involves being freed from the power of sinful desire. Note the theme of transformation by grace (see 1 John 3:2).

verses.text: For this very reason, make every effort to supplement your faith with virtue, and virtue with knowledge,
verses.comment: Peter encourages growth in Christian character. While faith is foundational, effort and cooperation in grace are required to develop further virtues—a pattern reminiscent of sanctifying growth stated elsewhere (see Phil. 2:12-13).

verses.text: and knowledge with self-control, and self-control with steadfastness, and steadfastness with godliness,
verses.comment: These virtues lead to spiritual maturity and are reminiscent of the fruit of the Spirit. Growth in knowledge and virtue demands discipline and perseverance in one's walk with God.

verses.text: and godliness with brotherly affection, and brotherly affection with love.
verses.comment: The highest virtue is love, which perfects all others (see 1 Cor. 13). Brotherly affection binds the community, and culminates in self-giving love, reflecting Christ's own command.

verses.text: For if these qualities are yours and are increasing, they keep you from being ineffective or unfruitful in the knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Spiritual fruitfulness flows from abiding in Christ with these virtues, echoing Jesus' teaching on the vine (John 15). Christian growth is not static, but must keep increasing.

verses.text: For whoever lacks these qualities is blind, short-sighted, having forgotten that he was cleansed from his past sins.
verses.comment: Forgetting the cleansing from past sins suggests neglecting the gift of spiritual new birth. The reference could point to baptism as the moment of cleansing (see 1 Pet. 3:21). Continued growth is needed to avoid spiritual amnesia.

verses.text: Therefore, brothers, be all the more diligent to confirm your calling and election, for if you practice these things, you will never stumble.
verses.comment: Assurance of salvation involves actively living out one's calling, not passivity. 'Calling and election' links with God’s initiative yet calls for ongoing human response, a harmony of divine and human cooperation.

verses.text: For in this way there will be richly provided for you an entrance into the eternal kingdom of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: The eternal kingdom is a present and future reality inaugurated by Jesus. Practicing the virtues is connected to our future hope of entering fully into God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Therefore I intend to remind you of these things, though you know them and are established in the truth that is present with you.
verses.comment: Peter aims to repeatedly remind the believers of foundational teachings, showing the importance of continual catechesis and spiritual formation.

verses.text: I think it is right, as long as I am in this earthly tent, to stir you up by way of reminder,
verses.comment: Peter refers to his body as a tent, demonstrating an understanding of life’s temporariness. Persistent spiritual reminders keep the faith alive and growing.

verses.text: since I know that the putting off of my tent will come soon, just as our Lord Jesus Christ has made clear to me.
verses.comment: Jesus foretold Peter’s martyrdom (see John 21), acknowledging the suffering and witness of church leaders. Peter’s awareness of impending death drives his urgency to teach.

verses.text: And I will make every effort, so that after my departure you may always be able to recall these things.
verses.comment: Peter expresses apostolic concern to ensure continuity of the apostolic teaching after his death—pointing to the enduring nature of leadership and tradition.

verses.text: For we did not follow cleverly devised myths when we made known to you the power and coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, but we were eyewitnesses of His majesty.
verses.comment: This claim of apostolic eyewitness to Jesus’ majesty refers particularly to the Transfiguration. The faith is grounded in historic events, not mere stories (see Matt. 17:1-6). Apostolic testimony is central for transmitting the faith.

verses.text: For He received honor and glory from God the Father when the voice was conveyed to Him by the Majestic Glory, 'This is My beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased.'
verses.comment: Direct reference to God’s declaration at the Transfiguration connects with Psalm 2:7. The Father’s testimony reveals Jesus’ divine Sonship. The supernatural affirmation of Jesus is at the heart of the apostolic witness.

verses.text: And we ourselves heard this voice carried from heaven when we were with Him on the holy mountain.
verses.comment: The apostles' direct hearing of the voice establishes their authority to hand on the message. Holiness of place and supernatural events highlight the sacred transmission of truth.

verses.text: And we have the prophetic word made more certain, to which you do well to pay attention as to a lamp shining in a dark place, until the day dawns and the morning star rises in your hearts.
verses.comment: The prophetic word, confirmed by Christ’s fulfillment, should guide believers until Christ’s return. The 'morning star' echoes Messianic titles and continues the theme of guidance through apostolic teaching.

verses.text: Above all, you must understand this: no prophecy of Scripture comes from someone’s own private interpretation.
verses.comment: Scripture is not subject to individualistic interpretation but must be received within the community formed by the apostles’ teaching. This is a vital principle for preserving the truth and unity of faith.

verses.text: For no prophecy was ever produced by human will, but men carried by the Holy Spirit spoke from God.
verses.comment: Scripture’s divine inspiration means that the Spirit leads the apostles and prophets. Divine guidance, not human initiative, brings about true prophecy. This continues the emphasis on the importance of apostolic and authorized transmission.
